description: {"blocks":[{"key":"1kro6","text":"This analytical procedure outlines a rapid and accurate method for the quantification of three key PET deconstruction products, namely terephthalic acid (TPA), 2-hydroxyethyl terephthalic acid (MHET), and bis(2-hydroxyethyl) terephthalic acid (BHET), using an ultra high performance liquid chromatography with diode array detection (UHPLC-DAD) system. This method combines the advantages of UHPLC for improved resolution and separation efficiency with the sensitivity of DAD for accurate and reliable quantification.\n\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

forks.title: PET Degradation Product Analysis by UPLC-DAD

creator.name: Stefan J. Haugen

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"40d63","text":"This protocol utilizes an ultra high performance liquid chromatography diode array detector (HPLC-DAD) system manufactured by Agilent Technologies as referenced in 'Materials'. A similar UHPLC-DAD system can be utilized however, some parameter nomenclature may deviate depending on the manufacturer. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fhar0","text":"Mobile Phase A:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"pvg1","text":"a solution of 20 mM phosphoric acid in UPW using the ratio of 1.34 mL of 85% phosphoric acid per 1 L of UPW. Ensure sufficient volume for analysis of all samples and standards.\n","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fojid","text":"Mobile Phase B:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ag3pm","text":"Methanol","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7998i","text":"Samples must be filtered through a 0.2 µm or smaller filter prior to injection on the UHPLC     ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"318ev","text":"Samples expected to be over the linear range of the instrument should be diluted to ensure accurate analysis and avoid carryover.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5mn83","text":"Terephthalic acid (TPA) preparation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8sbdo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9mf7k","text":"Prepare a buffer solution for the TPA standard","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"vqsk","text":"Prepare a 1M potassium phosphate dibasic (K2HPO4) buffer solution by weighing 87 g of K2HPO4 into 500 mL of 18.2MΩ⋅cm ultrapure water (UPW).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":43,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":47,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":87,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":91,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25ng9","text":"Prepare a 1M potassium phosphate monobasic (KH2PO4) buffer solution by weighing 68 g of KH2PO4 into 500 mL of UPW.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":46,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":49,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":90,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":93,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1gh0j","text":"Prepare a 1M phosphate buffer solution by combining 94 mL of K2HPO4 (dibasic) buffer and 6 mL of KH2PO4 (monobasic) buffer.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sub","offset":62,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":66,"length":2},{"style":"sub","offset":99,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":102,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ja60","text":"Check that the pH of the buffer solution is 8.0 ± 0.1 pH units (7.9-8.1). Adjust pH with 10N NaOH or concentrated phosphoric acid if necessary.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ar58l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"16u51","text":"Prepare the TPA standard","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8oreb","text":"Weigh out dry TPA standard and create 1000 µg/mL TPA stock standard using the phosphate buffer solution created in the previous step as the stock standard diluent. Example: Weighed 9,800 µg (9.8 mg) of powdered TPA and add 9.8 mL of phosphate buffer solution.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jpq9","text":"Create a 250 µg/mL TPA working standard using the 1000 µg/mL TPA stock standard and UPW as the diluent. Example: Pipetted 2.5 mL of 1000 µg/mL TPA stock standard and add 7.5 mL of UPW.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vq1","text":"Create the following calibration standards using the 250 µg/mL TPA standard working solution and UPW as the diluent.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aep79","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3iaiu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bvmf7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"7BE4E9574BC011F0B3DF0A58A9FEAC02","height":189,"id":592036,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"7cdnc\",\"text\":\"Example calibration curve preparation  for TPA (Click to enlarge)\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"TPA cal corrected.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t9bmbs5kp.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ucfebs5kp.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ucfdbs5kp.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"56ktt","text":"2-Hydroxyethyl terephthalic acid (MHET) preparation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":51}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2k6e9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2em06","text":"Prepare a 1:1 solution of UPW and tetrahydrofuran (THF)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d1o2t","text":"Weigh out neat MHET standard and create a 1000 µg/mL MHET stock standard using the 1:1 solution of ultrapure water (18.2MΩ⋅cm) and THF created in the step 2.1. Example: weigh 8,700 µg (8.7 mg) of powdered MHET and added 8.7 mL of 1:1 UPW and THF.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6envt","text":"Create a 250 µg/mL MHET working standard using the 1000 µg/mL MHET stock standard and the 1:1 solution of UPW and THF. Example: Pipetted 2.5 mL of 1000 µg/mL MHET stock standard and 7.5 mL of 1:1 UPW and THF solution.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"158h","text":"Create the following calibration standards using the 250 µg/mL MHET standard working solution and UPW as the diluent.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"461av","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d7ath","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9ovmr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"7924D5AA4BC111F0878C0A58A9FEAC02","height":186,"id":592038,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"5cl7h\",\"text\":\"Example calibration curve preparation  for MHET (Click to enlarge)\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"MHET cal corrected.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t9bqbs5kp.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ucfgbs5kp.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ucffbs5kp.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"96ekd","text":"Bis(2-hydroxyethyl) terephthalic acid (BHET) preparation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":56}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6d2or","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"80gcr","text":"Weigh out neat BHET standard and create a 1000 µg/mL BHET stock standard using tetrahydrofuran (THF). Example: Weighed 9,500 µg (9.5 mg) of powdered BHET and added 9.5 mL of THF.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"do84r","text":"Create a 250 µg/mL BHET working standard using the 1000 µg/mL stock standard and THF. Example: Pipetted 2.5 mL of 1000  µg/mL stock standard and 7.5 mL of THF.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"47apo","text":"Create the following calibration standards using the 250 µg/mL BHET standard working solution and THF as the diluent.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cg19f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qger","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"enaij","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9ic7n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"kuenk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"9D9F36714BC111F0B3DF0A58A9FEAC02","height":192,"id":592040,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"9il23\",\"text\":\"Example calibration curve preparation  for BHET (Click to enlarge)\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"BHET cal corrected.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/t9bsbs5kp.png","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ucfibs5kp.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/ucfhbs5kp.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5usbf","text":"Calibrations","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1082m","text":"All compounds must have a correlation coefficient (r2) of greater than or equal to 0.995 using a linear fit. It is recommended to weight the calibration with a 1/x weighting.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":52,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cs3kr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aekah","text":"Calibration verification standards","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dedku","text":"A calibration verification standard (CVS) is a standard from the calibration that is re-analyzed every 20 or fewer samples to ensure instrument drift remains within the determined acceptable criteria. Acceptable recoveries for this analysis are ±10% of the expected value. All reported data was bracketed by acceptable CVS recoveries. Acceptance criteria may differ between instruments and should be determined experimentally.


","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
